articles.headline: A Wily Banker Reaches the Top
articles.snippet: Michalis Sallas has thrived in Greece’s freewheeling business culture as head of Piraeus Bank, but financial oversight is increasing and may complicate his dealings.
articles.abstract: Michalis Sallas has thrived in Greece’s freewheeling business culture as head of Piraeus Bank, but financial oversight is increasing and may complicate his dealings.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Not long ago, Michalis G. Sallas, the chairman of Piraeus Bank in Greece, had a dream: to make his bank too big to fail.

articles.headline: From Apple, an Overhaul for Mobile and the Mac
articles.snippet: The company introduced a major redesign of its mobile software system, as well as upgrades for some Mac computers.
articles.abstract: The company introduced a major redesign of its mobile software system, as well as upgrades for some Mac computers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple wants to prove that it has not lost the ability to innovate in a post-Steve Jobs world.

articles.headline: A Rise in Requests From Brokers to Wipe the Slate Clean
articles.snippet: As investors rely increasingly on Finra’s database to vet Wall Street professionals, some brokers and executives are trying to remove complaints.
articles.abstract: As investors rely increasingly on Finra’s database to vet Wall Street professionals, some brokers and executives are trying to remove complaints.
articles.lead_paragraph: If an investor checked the securities industry’s official regulatory database of complaints against brokers for the name of Michele Kief, a Wells Fargo broker in Naples, Fla., it would reveal nine client disputes — enough red flags to give a customer pause.

articles.headline:
Banks Seen as Aid in
Fraud Against Older
Consumers
articles.snippet: Federal authorities and consumer lawyers say banks play a key role in giving questionable Internet merchants access to the financial system, enabling them to prey on consumers.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities and consumer lawyers say banks play a key role in giving questionable Internet merchants access to the financial system, enabling them to prey on consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pitch arrived, as so many do, with a friendly cold call.

articles.headline:
U.S. Drops Bid
to Limit Sales
of Morning-After Pill
articles.snippet: In a reversal, the Obama administration has decided to stop trying to block over-the-counter availability of the most popular morning-after contraceptive pill for all women and girls.
articles.abstract: In a reversal, the Obama administration has decided to stop trying to block over-the-counter availability of the most popular morning-after contraceptive pill for all women and girls.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has decided to stop trying to block over-the-counter availability of the best-known morning-after contraceptive pill for all women and girls, a move fraught with political repercussions for President Obama.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Pam Belluck

articles.headline: Tech Companies Tread Lightly in Statements on U.S. Spying
articles.snippet: Companies like Facebook and Google must balance the image of privacy protection with compliance with the law.
articles.abstract: Companies like Facebook and Google must balance the image of privacy protection with compliance with the law.
articles.lead_paragraph: Someone’s not telling the whole truth.

articles.headline: Maps That Live and Breathe With Data
articles.snippet: Maps that are dynamic, adapting to current conditions like traffic, are the most useful of all, which helps explain why Google wants to buy a popular social mapping service.
articles.abstract: Maps that are dynamic, adapting to current conditions like traffic, are the most useful of all, which helps explain why Google wants to buy a popular social mapping service.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Maybe real estate agents should start selling mobile phones on the side. Why? Because with phones, as with homes, location is everything.

articles.headline: Shootings by Agents Increase Border Tensions
articles.snippet: The killings of at least 15 people by United States Border Patrol agents have spurred criticism of the agency, which some say lacks oversight and accountability.
articles.abstract: The killings of at least 15 people by United States Border Patrol agents have spurred criticism of the agency, which some say lacks oversight and accountability.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOGALES, Ariz. — As rocks hurled from Mexico rained down on United States Border Patrol agents one night last October, at least one of the agents drew his gun and fired across the border, striking a teenager 11 times, 7 times in the back. The boy, José Antonio Elena Rodriguez, 16, collapsed and died on a cracked sidewalk blocks from his home, under a sign that read “emergencias médicas.” The police in Nogales, Mexico, reported that he had been carrying only a cellphone.

articles.headline: Debate on Secret Data Looks Unlikely, Partly Because of Secrecy
articles.snippet: Leaders in Congress and the intelligence committees strongly support the National Security Agency programs, and use national security arguments to trump privacy concerns.
articles.abstract: Leaders in Congress and the intelligence committees strongly support the National Security Agency programs, and use national security arguments to trump privacy concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden said he had leaked secret documents about National Security Agency surveillance to spark a public debate about civil liberties. President Obama, while deploring the leak, endorsed the same goal of a vigorous public discussion of the “trade-offs” between national security and personal privacy. “I think it’s healthy for our democracy, “ he said on Friday of the prospect of re-examining surveillance policy.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Chicago Tactics Put Major Dent in Killing Trend
articles.snippet: The police say they are tamping down retaliatory shootings between gangs by using a comprehensive analysis of the city’s tens of thousands of suspected gang members.
articles.abstract: The police say they are tamping down retaliatory shootings between gangs by using a comprehensive analysis of the city’s tens of thousands of suspected gang members.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A year after this city drew new attention for soaring gun violence and gang bloodshed, creating a political test for Mayor Rahm Emanuel in President Obama’s hometown, Chicago has witnessed a drop in shootings and crime. Killings this year have dipped to a level not seen since the early 1960s.

articles.headline: Turkish Police and Protesters Clash in Square
articles.snippet: Efforts to clear demonstrators from Taksim Square began a day after the prime minister agreed to meet with representatives of the protesters.
articles.abstract: Efforts to clear demonstrators from Taksim Square began a day after the prime minister agreed to meet with representatives of the protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Taksim Square erupted in chaos on Tuesday night as the riot police hit protesters with tear gas and water cannons, sending thousands of people fleeing down side streets, and Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey struggled to contain a political crisis that has threatened the nation’s economy and paralyzed the government.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, Sebnem Arsu and Ceylan Yeginsu

articles.headline: Atomic Power’s Green Light or Red Flag
articles.snippet: As the current generation of reactors moves toward retirement, a project in Georgia and one in South Carolina may be the industry’s last best hope.
articles.abstract: As the current generation of reactors moves toward retirement, a project in Georgia and one in South Carolina may be the industry’s last best hope.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAYNESBORO, Ga. — The two nuclear reactors rising out of the red Georgia clay here, twin behemoths of concrete and steel, make up one of the largest construction projects in the United States and represent a giant bet that their cost — in the range of $14 billion — will be cheaper than alternatives like natural gas.
